definitions.definition: water that has frozen and become solid

examples.text: There was ice on the windows.
The lake was covered with a sheet of ice.
the body of a man perfectly preserved in a block of ice
My hands are as cold as ice.
substantial loss of **sea ice** in the Arctic Ocean
Ice had formed on the pond.
Is the ice thick enough to walk on?
The ice was beginning to melt.
The spray froze and formed great blocks of ice on the front of the ship.

definitions.definition: a frozen surface that people skate on

examples.text: Both teams are on the ice, waiting for the whistle.
The dancers came out onto the ice.
People were skating on the ice.
They held hands as they glided across the ice.

definitions.definition: a piece of ice used to keep food and drinks cold

examples.text: I'll have lemonade please—no ice.
a glass of water with ice and lemon
She ordered a vodka and ice.
The glass was filled with green liquid and crushed ice.
Drinks, ices and popcorn are all on sale in the foyer.

definitions.definition: a type of sweet food that consists of ice that has been crushed (= broken into very small pieces) and given a sweet taste
to say or do something that makes people feel more relaxed, especially at the beginning of a meeting, party, etc.

examples.text: Jim organized a few party games to break the ice when people first arrived.

definitions.definition: to have no influence or effect on somebody

examples.text: His excuses cut no ice with me.

definitions.definition: kept cold by being surrounded by ice

examples.text: All the food is laid out and the champagne is on ice.

definitions.definition: not being dealt with now; waiting to be dealt with at a later time

examples.text: We've had to **put** our plans **on ice** for the time being.

definitions.definition: performed by skaters on an ice rink

examples.text: Cinderella on ice

wordOrigin: Old English īs, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch ijs and German Eis.
